Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: The use of right-to-left scripts in Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs) has presented several challenges. This memo provides a new Bidi rule for Internationalized Domain Names for Applications (IDNA) labels, based on the encountered problems with some scripts and some shortcomings in the 2003 IDNA Bidi criterion.

1. Introduction
contents.ja: 1.はじめに

contents.text: 1.1. Purpose and Applicability
contents.ja: 1.1。目的と適用

contents.text: The purpose of this document is to establish a rule that can be applied to Internationalized Domain Name (IDN) labels in Unicode form (U-labels) containing characters from scripts that are written from right to left. It is part of the revised IDNA protocol [RFC5891].
contents.ja: このドキュメントの目的は、右から左に書かれたスクリプトからの文字を含むUnicodeの形で国際化ドメイン名（IDN）のラベル（U-ラベル）に適用することができ、ルールを確立することです。これは、改訂されたIDNAプロトコル[RFC5891]の一部です。

contents.text: When labels satisfy the rule, and when certain other conditions are satisfied, there is only a minimal chance of these labels being displayed in a confusing way by the Unicode bidirectional display algorithm.
contents.ja: ラベルは、ルールを満たし、そして他の特定の条件が満たされた場合、唯一のUnicode双方向表示アルゴリズムによって混乱のように表示されているこれらのラベルの最小の可能性がある場合。

contents.text: The other normative documents in the IDNA2008 document set establish criteria for valid labels, including listing the permitted characters. This document establishes additional validity criteria for labels in scripts normally written from right to left.
contents.ja: IDNA2008ドキュメントセット内の他の規範文書は、許可された文字を一覧表示するなど、有効なラベルのための基準を確立します。この文書は、通常、右から左に書かれたスクリプト内のラベルのための追加的な有効性の基準を確立します。

contents.text: This specification is not intended to place any requirements on domain names that do not contain characters from such scripts.
contents.ja: この仕様は、そのようなスクリプトから文字が含まれていないドメイン名のいずれかの要件を配置するものではありません。

contents.text: In this memo, we use "network order" to describe the sequence of characters as transmitted on the wire or stored in a file; the terms "first", "next", "previous", "beginning", "end", "before", and "after" are used to refer to the relationship of characters and labels in network order.

contents.text: 2. The Bidi Rule
contents.ja: 2.双方向ルールに

contents.text: The following rule, consisting of six conditions, applies to labels in Bidi domain names. The requirements that this rule satisfies are described in Section 3. All of the conditions must be satisfied for the rule to be satisfied.
contents.ja: 次のルールは、6つの条件からなる、双方向のドメイン名のラベルに適用されます。ルールを満足するために、このルールを満たすには、セクション3に記載されている要件は、条件のすべてを満たす必要があります。

contents.text: 1. The first character must be a character with Bidi property L, R, or AL. If it has the R or AL property, it is an RTL label; if it has the L property, it is an LTR label.
contents.ja: 1.最初の文字は、双方向性のL、R、またはALの文字でなければなりません。それはRまたはAL性を有する場合は、RTLのラベルです。それはLの性質を持っている場合、それはLTRラベルです。

contents.text: 2. In an RTL label, only characters with the Bidi properties R, AL, AN, EN, ES, CS, ET, ON, BN, or NSM are allowed.

contents.text: 3. In an RTL label, the end of the label must be a character with Bidi property R, AL, EN, or AN, followed by zero or more characters with Bidi property NSM.

contents.text: 4. In an RTL label, if an EN is present, no AN may be present, and vice versa.

contents.text: 5. In an LTR label, only characters with the Bidi properties L, EN, ES, CS, ET, ON, BN, or NSM are allowed.

contents.text: 6. In an LTR label, the end of the label must be a character with Bidi property L or EN, followed by zero or more characters with Bidi property NSM.

contents.text: 3. The Requirement Set for the Bidi Rule
contents.ja: 3.双方向のルールに設定要件

contents.text: 4.2. Yiddish
contents.ja: 4.2。イディッシュ語

contents.text: Yiddish is one of several languages written with the Hebrew script (others include Hebrew and Ladino). This is basically a consonantal alphabet (also termed an "abjad"), but Yiddish is written using an extended form that is fully vocalic. The vowels are indicated in several ways, one of which is by repurposing letters that are consonants in Hebrew. Other letters are used both as vowels and consonants, with combining marks, called "points", used to differentiate between them. Finally, some base characters can indicate several different vowels, which are also disambiguated by combining marks. Pointed characters can appear in word-final position and may therefore also be needed at the end of labels. This is not an invariable attribute of a Yiddish string and there is thus greater latitude here than there is with Dhivehi.
contents.ja: イディッシュ語、ヘブライ語スクリプト（他の人がヘブライ語とラディノが含まれる）と書かれたいくつかの言語の一つです。これは基本的に（また、「アブジャド」と呼ばれる）子音のアルファベットですが、イディッシュ語は完全に母音である拡張形式を使用して書かれています。母音は、ヘブライ語で子音である文字を再利用することによるものであるそのうちの一つ、いくつかの方法で示されています。他の文字は、それらを区別するために使用される「ポイント」と呼ばれるマークを、組み合わせると、母音と子音の両方として使用されています。最後に、いくつかの基地文字もマークを組み合わせることにより、非曖昧化された、いくつかの異なる母音を示すことができます。尖った文字は単語最終的な位置に表示することができ、したがって、また、ラベルの最後に必要になる場合があります。これは、イディッシュ語の文字列の不変の属性ではなく、ディベヒ語であり、ここでより大きな自由度が存在します。

contents.text: It therefore appears appropriate for this repertoire also to be supported fully by IDNA. This presents no difficulty with characters in initial and medial positions, but pointed characters are regularly used in final position as well. All of the characters in the SYO repertoire appear in both marked and unmarked form with one exception: the HEBREW LETTER PE (U+05E4). The SYO only permits this with a HEBREW POINT DAGESH (U+05BC), providing the Yiddish equivalent to the Latin letter "p", or a HEBREW POINT RAFE (U+05BF), equivalent to the Latin letter "f". There is, however, a separate unpointed allograph, the HEBREW LETTER FINAL PE (U+05E3), for the latter character when it appears in final position. The constraint on the use of the SYO repertoire resulting from the proscription of combining marks at the end of RTL strings thus reduces to nothing more, or less, than the equivalent of saying that a string of Latin characters cannot end with the letter "p". contents.text: Consider the strings ALEF 5 (HEBREW LETTER ALEF + DIGIT FIVE) and 5 ALEF. Displayed in an LTR context, the first one will be displayed from left to right as 5 ALEF (with the 5 being considered right to left because of the leading ALEF), while 5 ALEF will be displayed in exactly the same order (5 taking the direction from context). Clearly, only one of those should be permitted as a registered label, but barring them both seems unnecessary.

contents.text: 5. Troublesome Situations and Guidelines
contents.ja: 5.面倒な状況とガイドライン

contents.text: There are situations in which labels that satisfy the rule above will be displayed in a surprising fashion. The most important of these is the case where a label ending in a character with Bidi property AL, AN, or R occurs before a label beginning with a character of Bidi property EN. In that case, the number will appear to move into the label containing the right-to-left character, violating the Character Grouping requirement.
contents.ja: 上記のルールを満たすラベルは意外な方法で表示される状況があります。これらの最も重要なのは、ラベルでは、BiDiプロパティーENの文字で始まる前に、双方向プロパティAL、AN​​、またはRの文字で終わるラベルが発生した場合です。その場合は、数が要件をグループ化文字に違反し、右から左へ文字を含むラベルに移動することが表示されます。

contents.text: If the label that occurs after the right-to-left label itself satisfies the Bidi criterion, the requirements will be satisfied in all cases (this is the reason why the criterion talks about strings containing L in some cases). However, the IDNABIS WG concluded that this could not be required for several reasons:
contents.ja: 右から左にラベル自体は双方向の基準を満たした後に発生するラベル場合は、要件が（これは基準がいくつかのケースではLを含む文字列について語る理由です）、すべての場合に満たされます。しかし、IDNABIS WGは、これはいくつかの理由のために必要とすることができなかったと結論付けました。

contents.text: o There is a large current deployment of ASCII domain names starting with digits. These cannot possibly be invalidated.
contents.ja: O数字で始まるASCIIドメイン名の大電流展開があります。これらはおそらく無効にすることはできません。

contents.text: o Domain names are often constructed piecemeal, for instance, by combining a string with the content of a search list. This may occur after IDNA processing, and thus in part of the code that is not IDNA-aware, making detection of the undesirable combination impossible.
contents.ja: Oドメイン名は、多くの場合、検索リストの内容を文字列を組み合わせることにより、例えば、断片的に構築されています。このことは、不可能で望ましくない組み合わせの検出を行う、IDNA処理後、及び従ってIDNA対応のないコードの一部に発生し得ます。

contents.text: o Even if a label is registered under a "safe" label, there may be a DNAME [RFC2672] with an "unsafe" label that points to the "safe" label, thus creating seemingly valid names that would not satisfy the criterion.
contents.ja: ラベルは「安全な」ラベルの下に登録されている場合でも、O、ので、基準を満たさないと、一見有効な名前を作成し、「安全」のラベルを指して「安全でない」のラベルを持つDNAME [RFC2672]があるかもしれません。

contents.text: o Wildcards create the odd situation where a label is "valid" (can be looked up successfully) without the zone owner knowing that this label exists. So an owner of a zone whose name starts with a digit and contains a wildcard has no way of controlling whether or not names with RTL labels in them are looked up in his zone.
contents.ja: Oワイルドカードゾーンの所有者は、このラベルが存在することを知らずに（正常に見ることができる）ラベルが「有効」である奇妙な状況を作成します。だから、名前を数字で始まり、ワイルドカードを含むゾーンの所有者は、それらの中にRTLラベルと名前が彼の地帯で検索されているか否かを制御する方法はありません。

contents.text: Rather than trying to suggest rules that disallow all such undesirable situations, this document merely warns about the possibility, and leaves it to application developers to take whatever measures they deem appropriate to avoid problematic situations.
contents.ja: むしろ、すべてのこのような望ましくない状況を禁止する規則を提案しようとするよりも、この文書では、単に可能性について警告し、彼らは問題の状況を回避することが適切と考えるどんな措置取るために、アプリケーション開発者にそれを残します。

contents.text: 6. Other Issues in Need of Resolution
contents.ja: 決議を必要としている6.その他の問題

contents.text: This document concerns itself only with the rules that are needed when dealing with domain names with characters that have differing Bidi properties, and considers characters only in terms of their Bidi properties. All other issues with scripts that are written from right to left must be considered in other contexts.
contents.ja: この文書では、唯一のBiDiプロパティーが異なるしている文字でドメイン名を扱う際に必要とされているルールで自身を懸念、そして唯一の彼らの双方向性の点で文字を考慮します。右から左に書かれたスクリプトとの他のすべての問題は、他のコンテキストで考慮されなければなりません。

contents.text: One such issue is the need to keep numbers separate. Several scripts are used with multiple sets of numbers -- most commonly they use Latin numbers and a script-specific set of numbers, but in the case of Arabic, there are two sets of "Arabic-Indic" digits involved.

contents.text: The algorithm in this document disallows occurrences of AN-class characters ("Arabic-Indic digits", U+0660 to U+0669) together with EN-class characters (which includes "European" digits, U+0030 to U+0039 and "extended Arabic-Indic digits", U+06F0 to U+06F9), but does not help in preventing the mixing of, for instance, Bengali digits (U+09E6 to U+09EF) and Gujarati digits (U+0AE6 to U+0AEF), both of which have Bidi class L. A registry or script community that wishes to create rules restricting the mixing of digits in a label will be able to specify these restrictions at the registry level. Some rules are also specified at the protocol level.

contents.text: Another set of issues concerns the proper display of IDNs with a mixture of LTR and RTL labels, or only RTL labels.
contents.ja: 問題の別のセットは、LTRとRTLのラベル、または唯一のRTLラベルの混合物とのIDNの適切な表示に関するものです。

contents.text: It is unrealistic to expect that applications will display domain names using embedded formatting codes between their labels (for one thing, no reliable algorithms for identifying domain names in running text exist); thus, the display order will be determined by the Bidi algorithm. Thus, a sequence (in network order) of R1.R2.ltr will be displayed in the order 2R.1R.ltr in an LTR context, which might surprise someone expecting to see labels displayed in hierarchical order. People used to working with text that mixes LTR and RTL strings might not be so surprised by this. Again, this memo does not attempt to suggest a solution to this problem.
contents.ja: アプリケーションが（一つには、テキストを実行するには、ドメイン名を識別するための信頼できるアルゴリズムが存在しない）、そのラベルの間に埋め込まれフォーマッティングコードを使用して、ドメイン名が表示されますことを期待するのは非現実的です。従って、表示順は、双方向アルゴリズムによって決定されるであろう。このように、R1.R2.ltrの（ネットワーク順で）配列が階層順に表示されるラベルを見て期待して誰かを驚かせるかもしれないLTRの文脈で順2R.1R.ltr、で表示されます。 LTRとRTLの文字列をミックスしたテキストでの作業に使用する人々は、このことにより、それほど驚くことではないかもしれません。ここでも、このメモは、この問題に対する解決策を提案しようとしません。

contents.ja: 7.互換性に関する注意事項

contents.text: 7.1. Backwards Compatibility Considerations
contents.ja: 7.1。後方互換性に関する注意事項

contents.text: As with any change to an existing standard, it is important to consider what happens with existing implementations when the change is introduced. Some troublesome cases include:
contents.ja: 既存の標準への変更と同じように、変更が導入されたときに、既存の実装と何が起こるかを検討することが重要です。いくつかの厄介な例は次のとおりです。

contents.text: o An old program used to input the newly allowed label. If the old program checks the input against RFC 3454, some labels will not be allowed, and domain names containing those labels will remain inaccessible.

contents.text: o An old program is asked to display the newly allowed label, and checks it against RFC 3454 before displaying. The program will perform some kind of fallback, most likely displaying the label in A-label form.

contents.text: o An old program tries to display the newly allowed label. If the old program has code for displaying the last character of a label that is different from the code used to display the characters in the middle of the label, the display may be inconsistent and cause confusion.

contents.text: One particular example of the last case is if a program chooses to examine the last character (in network order) of a string in order to determine its directionality, rather than its first. If it finds an NSM character and tries to display the string as if it was a left-to-right string, the resulting display may be interesting, but not useful.
contents.ja: プログラムではなく、その最初のものより、その方向性を決定するために、文字列の（ネットワーク順で）最後の文字を検査することを選択した場合最後の場合の特定の一例です。それはNSMの文字を見つけ、それが左から右への文字列であるかのように文字列を表示しようとすると、結果の表示は面白いが、有用ではないかもしれません。

contents.text: The editors believe that these cases will have a less harmful impact in practice than continuing to deny the use of words from the languages for which these strings are necessary as IDN labels.

contents.text: This specification does not forbid using leading European digits in ASCII-only labels, since this would conflict with a large installed base of such labels, and would increase the scope of the specification from RTL labels to all labels. The harm resulting from this limitation of scope is described in Section 5. Registries and private zone managers can check for this particular condition before they allow registration of any RTL label. Generally, it is best to disallow registration of any right-to-left strings in a zone where the label at the level above begins with a digit.

contents.ja: 7.2。前方互換性に関する注意事項

contents.text: This text is intentionally specified strictly in terms of the Unicode Bidi properties. The determination that the condition is sufficient to fulfill the criteria depends on the Unicode Bidi algorithm; it is unlikely that drastic changes will be made to this algorithm.

contents.text: 8. Security Considerations
contents.ja: 8.セキュリティの考慮事項

contents.text: The display behavior of mixed-direction text can be extremely surprising to users who are not used to it; for instance, cut and paste of a piece of text can cause the text to display differently at the destination, if the destination is in another directionality context, and adding a character in one place of a text can cause characters some distance from the point of insertion to change their display position. This is, however, not a phenomenon unique to the display of domain names.
contents.ja: 混合方向テキストの表示動作がそれに慣れていないユーザーに非常に驚くべきことができます。先が別の方向性のコンテキストにある場合、テキストは、先に異なっ表示させることができ、およびテキストの一つの場所に文字を追加するとの観点から文字にいくつかの距離を引き起こす可能性があり、たとえば、切断され、テキストの一部のペーストその表示位置を変更するための挿入。しかし、これは、ドメイン名の表示に固有のものではない現象です。

contents.text: The new IDNA protocol, and particularly these new Bidi rules, will allow some strings to be used in IDNA contexts that are not allowed today. It is possible that differences in the interpretation of labels between implementations of IDNA2003 and IDNA2008 could pose a security risk, but it is difficult to envision any specific instantiation of this.

contents.text: Any rational attempt to compute, for instance, a hash over an identifier processed by IDNA would use network order for its computation, and thus be unaffected by the new rules proposed here.

contents.text: While it is not believed to pose a problem, if display routines had been written with specific knowledge of the RFC 3454 IDNA prohibitions, it is possible that the potential problems noted under "Backwards Compatibility Considerations" could cause new kinds of confusion.
